contentrichtext.text: {{Refimprove|date=October 2009}} {{Infobox Airline | airline = Zip | image = Zip (airline) logo .svg | image_size = 150px | IATA = 3J | ICAO = WZP | callsign = Zipper | founded = September 2002 | commenced = | ceased = September 2004 | hubs = | secondary_hubs = | focus_cities = | frequent_flyer = | lounge = | alliance = | subsidiaries = | fleet_size = 12 | destinations = | parent = [[Air Canada]] | company_slogan = | headquarters = [[Calgary International Airport]] [[Calgary]], [[Alberta]] | key_people = Steve Smith | website = [http://web.archive.org/web/*/www.4321ZIP.com 4321ZIP.com] }} [[File:Zip Boeing 737-200 Davies.jpg|thumb|A Zip Boeing 737-200.]] '''Zip''' was a [[Canadian]] [[low-cost carrier|discount airline]] headquartered in Hangar 101 at [[Calgary International Airport]], [[Calgary]], [[Alberta]].<ref>"Directory:World airlines." ''[[Flight International]]''. 1-7 April 2003. "[http://www.flightglobal.com/pdfarchive/view/2003/2003%20-%200749.html?search="Zhejiang Airlines" p. 98]. "Hangar 101, 8050 22 Street North East, Calgary, Alberta, T2E 7H6, Canada"</ref> It was launched by [[Air Canada]] as a [[no-frills]] [[subsidiary]] in September 2002. It operated a fleet of 12 [[Boeing 737]] aircraft, each painted in a bright, [[neon]] colour ([[blue]], [[fuchsia]], [[green]], and [[Orange (colour)|orange]]) with a single class of service. The subsidiary was headed by former [[WestJet]] CEO, Steve Smith.<ref>Pigg, Susan. "[http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/thestar/access/421016591.html?dids=421016591:421016591&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Jan+22%2C+2003&author=Susan+Pigg&pub=Toronto+Star&desc=Zip%2C+WestJet+in+fare+war+that+could+hurt+them+both+%3B+Move+follows+competition+bureau+ruling+Battle+could+intensify+when+Zip+flies+eastward&pqatl=google Zip, WestJet in fare war that could hurt them both ; Move follows competition bureau ruling Battle could intensify when Zip flies eastward]." ''[[Toronto Star]]''. January 22, 2003. Business C01. Retrieved on September 30, 2009.</ref> As a direct competition to Canada's leading [[low-cost carrier]] WestJet, Zip flew mostly between the western cities of [[Abbotsford Airport|Abbotsford]], [[Calgary International Airport|Calgary]], [[Edmonton International Airport|Edmonton]], [[Vancouver International Airport|Vancouver]], [[Saskatoon Airport|Saskatoon]], [[Regina International Airport|Regina]] and [[Winnipeg International Airport|Winnipeg]]. Zip ceased operations in September 2004 when Air Canada resumed a full schedule on its western routes.{{Citation needed|date=May 2011}} ==Branding== Zip was known for branding its advertising with 3 character words. Among them, "yuk" was printed on the air sickness bags, "bag" was printed on the personal baggage tags, and "yum" was printed on the napkins distributed with beverages on board.
